title: Plywood panel linking joint for laser or router

description.text:
A new joint concept for linking panels together which lie in the same plane.
The squggly parts stretch ever so slightly like a spring to pull the panels together with a decent amount of force.
As a bonus, itâ€™s laser cutter friendly.  This joint could make it easier to build up large objects off of a smaller machine or from pieces of scrap.
This could also be suitable for something like a room divider panel, adult scale construction set, or maybe even a trampoline(!)

The notches that recieve the squiggly "springs" are elongated to provide adequate force in 1/2" chinese birch plywood.  
If you want to use a thinner or more flexible material, you will need to make these notches longer.
If you want to use a thicker or less flexible material, you will need to make these notches shorter.
A good step for adjustment in plywood might be around 0.015".  Again, work in progress :)

author: enone

description.text: This is a makercoin, an item designed to be able to test the capabilites of 3D printer. The coin is 6 cm in diameter and the thickness is 1.5 cm. This makercoin project was based of a combination of a beyblade and a fidget spinner. The part consists of to revolving parts, of which the outer part, consisting of blades, revolves around the inner part. Throughout the entire part, multiple cut extrudes were created systematically using the circular pattern command

Beyblade fidget spinner

We can split the construction of my "beyblade fidget spinner" into four segments. The first segment consisted of constructing the inner revolving part, which was created using a revolve. The next segment consisted of constructing the outer revolving part which was also created using a revolve. After creating a basic part that consisted of two components that are able to freely revolve around each other. The third segment consisted of performing numerous cut extrudes from the top view of the part. Many of these cut extrudes were created using the circular pattern command on various cut extrudes to develop the existing design. The fourth segment of this project consisted of using the fillet command on all edges. The first time this part was printed, the distance between the inner and outer revolving parts were too close and didn't result in a freely spinning "beyblade fidget spinner". So I increased the distance between these two parts to allow a " freely spinning base"

The initial planning and brainstorming of the "beyblade fidget spinner" consisted of ball bearings as the mechanism responsible for the revolving motion created by these two parts. However, soon after learning that ball bearings weren't the best option in creating the desired rotational motion. I simply created the inner part to be 3D printed within the outer revolving part with a small gap of 0.12 cm present to allow rotation.

title: Realacc X210 V+ "The Piggy" winter canopy pod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The snow is a winter-time part of a life here and I got sick of going home after every little crash or just inaccurate landing. Snow gets inside the electronics and even plastic-coated electronics gets malfunctions. I guess it's because of shortenings in parts like USB connector that isn't coated.
Well, I decided to make a canopy that will cover my build as good as possible from the snow. I'm not a designer or an artist of any sort, but I have a 3d printer and I can try.

To make sure that canopy will fit all of my components, I roughly modeled them in CAD and then made the canopy.

My build is:

  • Realacc X210 V+ frame
  • Matek FCHUB-VTX (PDB with video transmitter and pig-tail for antenna)
  • Matek F405-STD flight controller
  • Full sized RunCam Swift RR (first edittion with gopro lens by Rotor Riot)
  • FrSky X4R-SB receiver
  • Microphone from banggood
  • little buzzer
    All of those above covered by the canopy. The camera is tilted 30 degrees.

Funny that the result looks like little piggy, it even has a pig tail ;) I'm thinking to draw a piggy nose on camera lens cap... So I named it "The piggy".

I'm still in process of fitting everything together while waiting for next revision of the design with small fixes printed. Will post real photos of my quad after that. There are renders for now
Posted a photos of sucessfully assembled quad. The Piggy is in the air! =)

UPDATE 2018-03-12
Version 2:

  • a hole for USB connection
  • a plug that is better to print of TPU or some other flexible filament
  • altered an angle of the tubes for RX antennas to make 90 degree between them

Feel free to make holes or reshape it for your components, just dont forget to share your results here as a remix ;)
Here is the link to Fusion 360 project: http://a360.co/2D63o3M

My very first original Kingkong Tiny6 replacement frame.

Features:

  • No canope needed, lowrider.
  • Compartment that holds the receiver behind the camera
  • Top OR Bottom mounted battery customized battery chute

If you have a better way to mount the battery yourself you don't need the battery chute.

For top mounted battery chute:
Melt or glue it onto the pins after mounting it on top of the fc.

For bottom mounted battery chute

  • When assembling, first feed the camera and the rx through the center ring
  • Add the battery chute and lock it over the pins. (angled side towards the front)
  • Add the flight controller upside down (connectors facing up) on top of that, it clamps down automagically using the softmounts
  • Connect motor wires (left one right, right one left) and set 180degrees board rotation in Bettaflight

I printed and weighed it in PLA and that works. ABS or Nylon is probably stronger and somewhat lighter.

Good prints and good flights!

title: Media Center Case for RemotePi Board

description.text: This is a remix of Vitoveras's very nice media center case for the Raspberry Pi. I liked the attractive simplicity of the design and the way it routed the cables all in one direction. I had just installed the RemotePi Board on my RPI3 and needed a new case for it. I remixed this one to work with the RemotePi Board. I had to add a hole in the top of the case for the RemotePi Board button and I made the case a little taller so the top would be at the same height as the button. My RemotePi Board has the extended IR receiver so I added a hole in the case to run those wires out the front. And because I like to overclock my RPI3 I also added a 40mm fan mount. Other than that it is Vitoveras's design. On the top I printed I left the hold down clips where Vitoveras put them. I didn't realize until later that the RemotePi Board would interfere with one of them. I filed that clip a little on my top so that it would fit. I included an STL with that clip relocated so it should not interfere. But I have not printed that file since mine works fine now. Thanks Vitoveras for a very nice and functional design. I'm very happy with it.

KingBo is not only the newest edition to the Bos (the others are still a work in progress as of now), but he is also the king for a game of Chess! How convenient, eh? I will be working on the rest of a chess set as well as the Bos, so expect more soon!

Overview

I started by finding a design of a chess king I liked (I'll leave a link to that design below). I then started by revolving the very bottom of the base from a normal rectangle. I then used the spline tool to create the rest of the base and revolved it as well. I projected the geometry of the top face and extruded it with a taper. For the shoulders, I revolved two half-circles based on the guide lines and sketch geometry from the extrusion with the taper and connected the empty space between them by projecting the geometry. I then placed a plane within his shoulder, one slightly above, and one slightly above the second plane. I dimensioned the first circle 5mm on the first plane, the next 4mm on the second plane, and the last 5mm on the third plane. I lofted these. I then drew upon the XY axis and took an arc that extended from the back of his neck to the front of his neck at 45 degrees. Next, I swept the sketch geometry of the top of his neck along the arc, and drew two more arcs from that on XY plane; one shorter than the other. I then revolved these 180 symmetrically. For the eyes, I offset a plane from the YZ plane until I felt it was in the right spot. I the revolved the eyes, and offset a plane from the most recent plane to extrude circles in, giving the illusion of pupils. As for the crown, I started it similar to the neck. I placed a plane within his head and extruded it. I then extruded the sketch geometry of the top of that extrusion with a taper. Next, I created a spline from the edge of the tapered extrusion back the center at a higher point and revolved it. I then offset a plane within the crown and extruded another, smaller circle. I placed an arc on the XY plane straight up from the edge of this extrusion and connected it to the center with a line. I then offset a plane from the surface atop the most recent revolution, and placed a point in the center of the circle I extruded from the crown. I then lofted the flat part of the crown point to the point on the plane.
Inspiration: https://www.bing.com/images/search?view=detailV2&ccid=TYTxoiDu&id=605A3875B861D882BF3DCC812D33604C0F087FBE&thid=OIP.TYTxoiDufNWVN6lB3ATpCQHaHa&mediaurl=http%3a%2f%2fwww.herendstore.com%2fv%2fvspfiles%2fphotos%2fHSVHNM-15114-0-00-2.jpg&exph=1000&expw=1000&q=chess+peice+king&simid=608032358959746143&selectedIndex=40&ajaxhist=0

Apparently they don't make parts for Jean Babtise trumpets so I decided to make my own. I wrote down my specific module but it should work on any trumpet with similar threading.

author: thomassmith1969

title: Powder Scoops - Graduated Spoons - CC Measuring Spoons

description.text:
I have recently gotten into reloading and needed a set of graduated scoops. Since I downloaded the Case Feeder for my Hornady LNL AP Press here on thingiverse, I thought I'd give back by designing a set of scoops for the community. I used OpenSCAD and did all of the programming myself. I even learned a couple new things in the process.

The basis of this design was to create a series of volumetric scoops to get in the ballpark of a load. Then trickle feeding in the difference. The scoop capacity is in cubic centimeters, therefore the design was also done in centimeters. This made calculating the size of the scoop relatively easy. Essentially I used a desired capacity to calculate the size and shape of a hemisphere and cylinder that sits on top of it. These two primitives' combined volume is equal to the desired capacity. I believe the math is right here, but I welcome constructive feedback if not. Also, the actual capacity may vary slightly with printer, material, temperature, and other factors.

I initially based my concept off of the Lee Dippers set, which has 16 scoops measured in cubic centimeters.

I have included what I called the Lee Set. A single STL with all of the scoops that match the capacity of the scoops that Lee provides.

I also included what I called the Super Set which is a set of 50 scoops from 0.1 to 5.0 cc in 0.1 cc increments.

And there is also each scoop in its own STL, in case you want to get specific and just print one or two.

Lee Dippers Chart here: https://leeprecision.com/cgi-data/instruct/Dippers.pdf

We're currently running a Kickstarter campaign for the extended range of our ScatterBlocks (quick-assembling miniature terrain), so drop on by and drop us a pledge if you want the full range. For those of you supporting us (or thinking about supporting us) on Patreon, all the rewards will go to our backers there as well (as we do with all our crowdfunding campaigns).

This miniature is one of many that will be included in our new game, Wrath & Ruin (currently in development), (as part of the "Earthbound" faction), a blend of simple miniature wargaming and physical boulder-throwing (check out the videos). We're pretty excited about this one, and would love to get others in on the play testing phase before we expand and go wider with the game. Kickstarter backers at the $25 level and Patreon supporters will get the play tester kit in March (after the current campaign wraps).

The True Gnome, like all the miniatures we're designing for this game, prints without the need of support material. We printed ours without a raft and at a .1 layer height with 10% infill.

Enjoy!

Usually the drawers fit together just fine, sometimes I get a little bit of stringing if I rush things too much but just running the T slots together a few times makes everything smooth.

description.text:
This is a set of modular drawers which interlock and are infinitely expandable. The basis of this design is to produce drawers that can be printed at high extrusion speeds and will fit together without tolerance issues. The system uses regularly spaced T slots with ample clearance to fit together loosely and built in springs to provide friction to keep the drawer boxes aligned. The system also uses a small beam across the top of the drawer body which acts as a drawer stop to limit the drawers travel as well as to reinforce the top of the drawer box if loaded (In practice the number of spring loaded T joints tends to distribute the load well). Larger drawers have thicker walls than smaller drawers for increased strength. The drawers are based on 1" increments. The smallest drawers are 1"x1" however the larger size drawers are really based on 1"+ the joint thickness.

I have already revised the design a bunch of times to make things fit together nice and to get the slots to fit easy but hold where you place them. I will be interested to know if they work as well as they do for me for others.

One further note. This is based on a parametric model so that I could get different drawer sizes easily and control tolerances and wall thickness via spreadsheet. Based on the way it is made if you print the drawer dividers they will need to be rotated to lie flat on the printer bed. The drawers and boxes should load in the correct orientation to print.

remixed_from.title: Glass Plate Corner Brackets for Flashforge Inventor 3D Printer

title: Glass Plate Corner Brackets for Flashforge Inventor 3D Printer (Remix)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These corner brackets were designed to interface with the Flashforge Inventor 3D printer and the glass plate upgrade from Flashforge USA. Supports glass dimension (L x W x H) 9 x 6 x 0.15 inches. Glass must be installed on top of the Flashforge build tape and aluminum build plate. You may require four washers to prevent the hex nuts from going through the gaps of the corner brackets.

The corner brackets are designed to be of sufficiently low profile to accommodate the build plate movements in proximity of the internal filament spools. The corner brackets can be fastened using the existing build plate hardware and are flush with the surface of the glass.

I would like to say that this project worked on the first attempt but it would be false. What started as a deliberate design attempt turned into a series of trial and error. It took me seven versions to get it right.

Printer:

Flashforge Inventor

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

In order for these brackets to work at bed temperatures up to 110 degrees Celsius, I recommend using Proto-Pasta Carbon Fiber HTPLA for printing these and then following directions from Proto-Pasta for annealing. I do not recommend the use of regular PLA or ABS for this project as they will become soft and rubbery during heated bed operation.

Each corner bracket file is labelled with a letter A, B, C, or D. Refer to the included photo to determine where each corner bracket goes.

To ensure compatibility with your system, here are the measured dimensions of the parts that the brackets interface to:

Original Aluminum + PCB + Tape Build Plate (L x W x H) 232 x 153 x 8.25mm
Glass Plate Upgrade (L x W x H) 229 x 152.45 x 3.8mm

I recommend tightening the nuts once the build plate is fully raised and pre-heated to 60-70 degrees Celsius.

Step 1: New Enhancements

After having used the source version of these for two months, I discovered some areas for improvement. I increased the height of the opening that interfaces with the "Original Aluminum + PCB + Tape Build Plate" by 0.2mm in order to get an even better fit. I also reinforced the external sides of the corner brackets as they seemed to start warping slightly at 110 degrees Celsius (even with the annealed Proto-Pasta Carbon Fiber HTPLA). I think that with the thicker material, which is an insulator, the part should maintain its shape.

description.text:
Deep within the castle of the Crystal in the world of Thar, the curel and twisted Skekis took control and slowly drained the world around them. As dark and wicked as these creatures were, what they created within the bowels of the castle, would go on to spared terror and destruction for many years. The Garthim solders, were the main enforcers of the Skekis's will.These imposing figures were not only built for strength but for speeds as well. Massive, unyielding, merciless, virtually indestructible, and always in vast numbers, these monsters would aid their masters in ravaging the land and leaving little in the wake, and whatever or who ever they didn't destroy they often captured and dragged back with them to the castle, never to be seen or heard from again.

        I was actually shocked when I realized that no one had tried to create a 3D print of these guys yet. I grew up with a weird relationship with them and loved to fear them, which later turned into a fascination. This model was based of of some still images and some original concept art made by Brain Froud. I also got some inspiration from this much better version by SeithCG (which you should totally check out).

http://seithcg.com/wordpress/?p=1195

remixed_from.title: Spool Roller for Folger Tech 2020 i3

title: Spool Holder for Z8XM2 / 2040 V Slot Extrusion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original spool holder that came with my Zonestar Z8XM2 was well... lacking.
First of all, the standoffs were not long enough to fit my spools and I first modified them to hold a spool. However, I still did not like them.

So I decided to search thingiverse for a spool holder. The closest one I found that I liked was the Spool Roller for Folger Tech 2020 i3.
Unfortunately, this was for 2020 extrusion. My printer's horizontal piece on top is 2040 extrusion.
So I set off to design my own based upon QuadBert's design. (Thanks for putting that out there!)

What you see is what I designed. The width is adjustable by simply sliding one of the holders. They can be locked in place with an M5 screw, 6mm I believe, and a T-nut. (or as Zonestar calls them, a boat nut, Lol)
The bearings are standard 608zz bearings and you'll need (4) per spool holder set.
To hold the 'cap' onto the main body, you'll need (4) M3 screws around 6 to 8 or 10mm. The holes are designed so the screw threads into the plastic. Obviously you don't want to crank down on them, they just need to hold the cap onto the main body.

This runs MUCH better than the factory spool holder. I've been very happy with them.
I also included the Fusion 360 file in case you want to modify it.

Hopefully this helps. If it does, feel free to leave a tip!
Enjoy!

Zonestar Z8XM2

author: Anubis_

description.text:
This is a small bridge made to span a 5-inch gap for a school project. the truss proved to be very sturdy, holding a total of 30kg before failing catastrophically. Weighing in at only 18g (not counting the metal rods in the joints as they do not impact the strength of the actual truss) this truss can hold 1666.667 times its own weight.

Attached files are:
A picture of the bridge in the testing rig
A picture of the bridge with the heaviest load born before breaking

A picture of all members fresh off the printer
a picture of the members being weighed

An STL for each individual member
An STL of all the members plated and ready to print (sized to a 200mm/120mm plane)

A screenshot of the Member load Calculations according to MDSolids

Bridge Assembly & Testing

the Bridge itself is held together using 7 2.75" 3mm smooth shafts. Load was placed in the exact center, and a bucket and rocks (as well as a small scale) were used to load the bridge until failure, at which point the bucket was weighed and final load computed.

Key Design decisions

The truss design was made to be as simple as possible without sacrificing too much strength. A static load was simulated using MDSolids, a screenshot of the final statics calculations is included.

Multiple test members of varying diameters and infills were printed and tested for compression and tension, before arriving at the decision to use members at 50% infill and .2" diameter to bear compression, with members at 50% infill and .1" diameter to bear tension.

description.text: Recycling your failed prints can be a lot of fun, but I needed a place to hold all of my failed prints, rafts, etc. Enter "The Bin of Broken Hopes and Dreams." It's a place to store all of your failed prints, but it's so much more. it's also a message of hope, a reminder that even if your 30-hour print blew up on you at hour 21, you're still a good person. The lid also contains Douglas Adams' eternal message of hope, reminding you that there is no need to panic, even if your hot end is so buried in deformed plastic that you can't see the nozzle. So print it out, and take solace in knowing that you're not the only one who needs a place to lay your broken hopes and dreams to rest.

description.text:
This Bitcoin is different. Address and Key created offline. "See youtube video on how to, creating "Cold Wallets". You can put money in many times, but remove all at once. This coin would have the key embedded into the center during printing.
My Idea of this was for those people who feel they need a physical form of currency. If you do it right you can scan the printed QR code and check the balance on your phone. When your ready to spend you break the coin open get the key out and scan that QR code; to SWEEP the entire amount into a hot wallet.

Steps;

  1. Create a paper wallet offline
  2. screen cap the BitCoin QR address (do Not Screen Cap The Key QR)
  3. Print out Paper Wallet. x2,one for back up
  4. clear out any evidence of Key address from computer. Go back on line.
  5. Use tinker cad to place a 3d image of your Address QR (NOT KEY QR) on the blank side of the coin.
    -.1mm thick
    -11.9mm in elevation
    Does take some trial and error for this (it's a practice makes perfect type of thing)
  6. I sliced at .1mm. QR might show up better at .06mm. More detail better the QR can be read from a camera.
  7. At roughly 66% during slice Pause or if your quick, slip in the cut out piece of the KEY QR code from the paper wallet and put it in.
  8. At roughly 86% change the filament color to black (this is for the Address's QR code)

Please tip Bitcoin, i'm just having fun with cryptocurrency .

author: Nick_Shl

title: DIN rail keystone jack RJ45 module low profile mount (lying / EN 50022)

description.text:
What can you expect?

This small case houses all types of CAT 6A keystone jack modules I have at home but it should work for a lot of other RJ45 keystone jack modules as well.
It allows to install them on a 35mm EN 50022 DIN rail in a lying direction.
The module is 16.5mm wide and fits into the allowed width of a DIN 43880 slot.
The height measured from the DIN rail to the top is <33mm.
The over-all length of the case is 50mm (CAT7 cable comes out to one end and RJ45 jack is inserted into the other)
This is only tested with about 5 different brands/models of keystone jacks I already had at home and not guaranteed to work with yours!

Motivation

I needed to install my network CAT 6A modules on a DIN rail in a very low profile multimedia box. I could not find one shop selling such modules and so I had to create them myself.

Printer Brand:

Duplicator 4

Printer:

Wanhao

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This model is easy to print. Every well-tuned printer with a <=0.4mm nozzles should print it well. I'm sure printing it with a 0.2mm layer height will also work and only result in a little less clean finish of the part.
I always use ABS filament to print parts like this. ABS is cheap and has a high mechanical load capacity. Its chewy stiffness makes it easy to cut threads into it.
In this case we only need to cut threads with self-cutting 2mm wide screws into it which would also work with PLA for example. PETG would also work and would even end-up being chewier but the tendency to create a lot of hairy filament strings if tool head is traveling around is something you need to take care. So in case you want to print it with PETG use a slicer which allows you to configure a really high detour factor to avoid crossing outlines for travel movements.

A printed (A) and (B) side of the case - see downloadable stl files 4 pices of 2mm wide and 10mm long self-cutting counter sunk screws

They are typically not available in small town hardware stores. If you have time for waiting you can order them from China for about $1.50 including shipping costs for a bag of 100 hundred of those screws.

A RJ45 keystone jack module you want to mount in this case

description.text:
Update 3/11: Added a bottom piece that accessories can be mounted to as well as an attachment for a 50mm blower targeted for a Volcano. I also have a beta for a regular V6 heater block if anyone wants to try it.

This is the modified X-Carriage I have been using on my FT-5. This carriage fixes a number of inconveniences us FT-5 users endure. The differences between this upgraded carriage and the original (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1858771) are:

  • Solid pieces: The rail and motor attach to the same piece. The screws are fully backed - shouldn't bend or break like the default carriage. The attachment holes have divots to ensure everything stays in place and not the straight, tight square holes. All bolt heads and nuts are counter sunk.

  • Mount for a small 8-circuit terminal block (https://www.amazon.com/Blue-Sea-Systems-Circuit-Terminal/dp/B000S5Q2VS): I change my hot ends, coolers, thermistors, etc often. A terminal block is a lot easier to deal with than crimping every new wire.

  • Cut out for motor plug: You can remove the motor without having to disassemble the entire carriage. Remove the rear motor screws and it will pull out the front.

I dropped the cable chain but the stock chain should mount to the top holes. I velcroed my cable rope to the rail 'hat' from my dual bowden gantry (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2814954).

This is still WIP. Everything works great but I will be creating a part cooler that mounts to the carriage and a piezo sensor mount once the parts arrive.

Printer:

FT-5

Infill:

25

Notes:

Everything should print pretty easily. Use supports to keep the divots and counter sunk holes well-formed. Use decent infill for structure.

description.text:
(Long - the full story) (Scroll down to skip all the yada yada)

My FLSUN PRUSA i3 Clone instructed me to wire my extruder heat sink fan from the "constant on" 12v power supply on the Makerbase board it came with. Meaning, as soon as I powered on the printer, the extruder fan was on as well...All.The.Time... printing or not. It was a smart idea at the time for me as I was just getting started with 3D printing and had no idea what I was doing and how big of a role that fan plays in the printing process. As I figured out later on, there was actually another 12v fan power supply connector on the board to enable the use of g-code on/off commands. Upon finding this out, I immediately switched over the wiring and began to use the automated g-code for turning the fan on/off. As I quickly found out, sometimes because of how fast I was changing out print jobs or starting and aborting prints while troubleshooting, sometimes that fan just didn't kick back on and I wouldn't notice it because it was supposed to be automatic and I was too focused on whatever it was I was trying to print. Ergo...clogs for days. So, back to the original wiring setup. Well now that I know everything (ha ha ha) about my printer and the process of printing... well that fan always being on has just become down right annoying, running all the time, not to mention having to replace it every few months as my printer is running nearly 24/7...

(Short) To help eliminate power draw through/from my MakerBase board I decided to make this part for an easily accessible and simple to place option to house a switch for flipping the fan on/off as needed while running power to the fan directly from my power supply.

JICYWTK - The 2nd switch is for my light bar.

Printing notes below...

Rocker Switch: http://a.co/cTNxCfx

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

100%

Notes:

Printing as is with support "touching table" (Cura) worked fine for me. My biggest concern was that the t-slot clips on the bottom would snap off during installation but neither of mine did and seemed quite sturdy overall. However, if you plan to move them frequently, I would suggest flipping the model 90 degrees so that the clips are printed "with the grain" of the box to prevent this from happening or printing with a lower resolution may help to strengthen the clips printed as is. Do what works best for you!

remixed_from.title: momo wheel paddle extender for Logitech g27

description.text:
I like to do different types of sim racing personally, so naturally there are different rims for my different needs. There are many many parts out there for the logitech wheels but I haven't found a single paddle shifter that allowed conversion between 270mm rims and 350mm rims. I made this so that I could play with a 270mm f1 wheel while using a 350mm rim for gt, rally and so on.

I remixed this from a paddle extender that uses the original logitech shift paddles and took the mounting arms for the logitech wheel from it. For mounting instructions please check out the description of the paddle extender. You will need 2 m3 nuts and bolts for each side though.

The design is pretty simple, there is an f1 shift paddle for 270mm rims and there is a gt style paddle extender to make it compatible with 350mm wheels. All you need to do is put 2 bolts through the 2 holes of the f1 shifter into the gt style paddle extender then use 2 nuts to fasten them. For both sides you will need 4 sets of m3 nuts and bolts in total.

According the the paddle extender, you will have to mirror the f1 shift paddles for use for the right side.

Here is my version of a sensor mount for the ANet A8. On that other sensor mounts, the sensor blocked some way or collided with some other printed part, so I moved it in front of that fan and in the same time replaced that fan cover so that I can still use the original screws.

Offset settings at my printer are X=-42 and Y=-7

description.text:
I remixed this Blast Gate for use with the 2" (50 mm) pipe that is used in home built in vacuum installations. I plan to use it in a dust collection system for my small shop. I don't have any need for a giant system with 4" pipe as I will just be using it on my CNC and a couple of small tools. The 2" pipe is available at most hardware stores, is reasonably priced and there are a good assortment of fittings available for it.

I included the locking holes in the shell, although the fit is quite tight in the shell, so I don't think I will need them, but they are there if you do.

The .step files are also included if you would like to make any changes.

Edit:
Tightened up the holes a bit to keep parts better aligned and added a printed set screw as I wasn't fond of the bolt. Set Screws can be found on Amazon or eBay, but this works fine.

I used 1/4" X 3/4" long bolts to hold it all together. The shell and spacer are pretty solid at the holes, but it is plastic so not too tight.

I was having problems getting the threads for the set screw to be loose enough to fit easily in Fusion 360 and in the end, I decided it was just easier to chase the threads with a tap and die set (1/4" UNC20).

description.text: Dibujo 3D PREDATOR

print_settings.Notes:: Honestly, you know your printer and filament better than I do, so do what you think will work.  I'm still experimenting with mine and with different filaments, so just think about how much weight your wheel is and how tough you'll need it to be.  If you want to be sure it'll hold up, 50% infill will work no problem.  I kicked my msuper v3s+ while it was in the stand and it didn't fall over.  The stand held up great.  I'll update once I have the 10% infill one completed.

description.text: Used tinkercad to merge the pieces, then stuck solid blocks and cylinders to fill the empty holes. This is for the larger wheels, so if you want to use it on the smaller wheels, you'll have to squeeze the stand in a bit. I tried it with smaller wheels and it's too wide, so the wheel just falls in between the two supports.

Notes:

Infill depends on the wheel you have. I'm testing 10% right now with an octet pattern, but my previous one was 50% infill with 2mm wall thickness. Hopefully my 1.2mm wall thickness 10% octet infill will hold up. :P

Honestly, you know your printer and filament better than I do, so do what you think will work. I'm still experimenting with mine and with different filaments, so just think about how much weight your wheel is and how tough you'll need it to be. If you want to be sure it'll hold up, 50% infill will work no problem. I kicked my msuper v3s+ while it was in the stand and it didn't fall over. The stand held up great. I'll update once I have the 10% infill one completed.

Print it with the wall side facing the bed.

In principle, you can print it without supports, because every printer can do 45° angles fairly well. I printed my first one without supports. However, I would not recommend: While the middle tube prints well, the side sticks start swinging as they get longer and their shape becomes clumsy. But it works.

My second one is printed with supports touching the bed. So just the side sticks had supports. It came out much nicer, but the print time was longer.

Filament spools have various sizes of their inner holes. I've designed an adapter to cope with that.

The adapter uses a konus to adjust to individual spools. The adapter's inner hole fits onto an 8mm rod.

I've intentionally not used any ball bearings, because the spool must produce some resistence when unwinding the filament. My earlier trials with ball bearings didn't have such resistence and ended up with too much unwinding and clogging of filaments.

description.text:
If you have made this thing and find it is useful, a lot of filament being wasted together with time and effort being put in to produced this design. Please consider leaving a tip. Thanks!

My new design E3D v6 clone x-carriage for Anet A6 which I like call it ZEUS X-Carriage.

Through numerous trial and error, from filament jams and clogging of nozzle. This is the final designed I came out that works flawlessly with any filament I throw at it. And this x-carriage is designed for e3d v6 clone with full metal throat. This X-Carriage E3D v6 Heat sink must be cooled using 2 powerful 30mm cooling fan installed in a Push Pull configuration to PREVENT jamming experienced by numerous user.

This is a modular x carriage design and it is designed to be used as direct drive or bowden. It has the mount for the following extruder or configuration:-

  1. Direct Drive with 3d Printed NSTT Extruder with 3 to 1 Gear reduction ratio. Extruder can be downloaded from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2090259

  2. Direct Drive with E3D Titan extruder with 3 to 1 gear reduction ratio.

  3. Direct Drive with Anet A6 Stock Extruder (Mk8 Extruder)

  4. Bowden setup.

Also include a BL Touch mount for those who want to use BL touch auto bed levelling.

3d printed bushing for this x-carriage can be obtained here

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2766583

The included circular fan duct works for both standard hot end or volcano hot end

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Top and Bottom layer - 5
Parameter - 4

comments.text: I don't know if you plan on printing this at some point, but you might find it works a lot better printing sideways (like in the STL file) with support, as opposed to how it is oriented in your rendering. This is because 3d printed parts are most likely to fail due to delamination (layers coming apart), so the "prongs" are likely to break. If you print it sideways, you'd have to snap the body in half, which is a lot less likely.
comments.author: jamesglanville

description.text:
Hey Everyone,

There have been some great organisers for mini paints on here for a while, and while many of them help organise a workspace they don't really work in my world where I don't have a set painting space. Set up and pack up eat too much into my time and this often results in me just watching Netflix instead of painting some sweet minis.

So here we have my solution, it stores 30 Citadel paints, has a draw just long enough for my brushes (187 mm) and the lid comes off easily so it can be used as a paint pallet/wet pallet.

Parts list:
14 m3 x 4 x 5 knurled nuts like these:
https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/M1-4-M1-6-M2-M2-5-M3-Brass-Insert-Threaded-Decorative-Embedded-Knurled-Nuts/132382302605?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=431717369415&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

14 m3 x 8mm socket head cap screws. (any m3 x 8mm screws will be fine)
https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/M3-M8-12-9Grade-Alloy-Steel-Stainless-Allen-Hex-Socket-Cap-Head-Screw-Bolt-HOT/322973268766?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=512112924489&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

14 or 28 m3 washers.
https://www.ebay.com.au/itm/DIN125-Stainless-Steel-Flat-Plain-Washers-M1-6-M2-M2-5-M3-M4-M5-M6-M8-M10-M12/322145381613?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&var=511058843577&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

The knurled nuts are inserted buy heating them with a soldering iron and pressing them into the holes already in the printed parts.

description.text:
I found the original leaf here:
https://fr.dreamstime.com/images-libres-de-droits-silhouette-squelettique-de-feuille-sur-le-fond-blanc-illustration-de-vecteur-image29745479

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

N/A

Notes:

This is a challenging print. The slicer cuts everything into small line fragments, so the printer has to retract the filament continuously.

The result is somewhat disappointing. Maybe it's more suitable for laser cutter...

Gimp
  1. Cropped the image.
  2. Increased contrast until only black and white remains.
InkScape
  1. Imported the PNG image.
  2. Created vector using trace bitmap.
  3. Created a copy of the shape (named fill and stroke)
  4. Added 1.5px thick stroke to the "stroke" shape (to create a buffer to make it printable).
  5. Converted the stroke shape to path.
  6. Union paths ("stroke" and "fill" shapes).
  7. Saved as OpenSCAD using my InkScape extension:
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2805184
OpenSCAD
  1. Open the OpenSCAD document created by InkScape.
  2. Added linear extrusion.

title: Handle for Allen/Hex Wrench/Key with Screw or "Snap"

description.text:
As I was contemplating printing this I saw a comment asking for a screw version and wanted to try out openscad so I made this remix to use an m3 screw and avoid using zip-ties.

The screw hole is automatically slightly undersized from whatever you input as the diameter. I'm using M3 screws. Depending on your material/printer tolerances, be careful threading the screw as if it is too tight, you may crack the thin surrounding areas.

Prints without support

Update:
Added text - I removed one of the "knurls" on the handle and added some cutout text for labeling such as M2 or 7/64"

Update 2:
Added an option to use jssammon's Removable locking version. I made some changes though, removing the Z-height compensation because that seemed more like a printer-specific support issue to me, and made the locking channel slightly tighter so it should "snap" into place. Keep in mind, the handle is weaker turning left than right due to the slot made by the locking feature.

Updated the chamfer around the screw-head hole so it should work with larger diameters.

Turned the height adjustment of wrench placement/locking features into a variable at the top.

author: McGiverGim

description.text:
Parts for a thumb piano that uses pieces of bandsaw blade or other scrap for keys.   
It has a partial hole in the rear sized for a standard 1/4" mono phone jack for attaching to an amplifier. See instructions.

Print lid, box, bridge. The lid is designed to be a very tight press-fit when printed on a well-tuned printer. Otherwise it may need a little scraping.  
The slits at the rear of the lid are 4mm wide. if you want to use wider blades (hacksaw blades?) for keys, then knock out some of the 1mm dividers to make room. Grind off the teeth and any sharp edges, obviously.  
I haven't tried tuning this yet, but there are up to 14 slots available.   
Slide the bridge under the keys into whatever slot you need, to prevent buzzing. See pics.  
If you want the electric option, epoxy a piezo buzzer disk to the underside of the lid and wire it to a 1/4" mono phone jack. Then a standard guitar cable will connect it to an amp.  
No other electronics are required, just the disk and jack. These disks can be purchased or salvaged from a timer or almost any other equipment that "beeps."  
Video and cover of "Freebird" coming soon.

Designed these creepy little things in Tinkercad for the kids. After printing, there's a pry point at the end of the butt/tail to get you started in removing it from your print bed. Then fold and snap (or cut) off the long leg anchors. The centipede is around 140mm square, which is about as big as I can print on my Qidi X-One. They'll scale down a bit if you need it smaller. And they certainly scale up! They print nicely hollow with two perimeter layers, but I ended up printing them at 100% infill for more creepy weight. Printing at less than 0.200 layer height may cause adhesion problems where the feet attach (i.e. a leg may fall over before connecting with the body)

Como al tratar texto en Freecad tuve un problema, para practicar hice un llavero para la cafetería donde habitualmente desayuno. El problema era que al decirle al Freecad donde se encontraba el tipo de letra (fonts) me daba error, entonces recordé que esto ya me había sucedido y era que hay que poner el archivo del tipo de letra en una carpeta que sea accesible y no del sistema, es el caso de la carpeta Documentos.

Traducción Google:
As when I was dealing with text in Freecad I had a problem, to practice I made a keychain for the cafeteria where I usually eat breakfast. The problem was that when I told Freecad where the font (fonts) was, it gave me an error, then I remembered that this had already happened to me and it was that I had to put the font file in a folder that was accessible and not of the system, is the case of the Documents folder.

A little twist clip for keeping mouse cords from becoming a rat's nest.

It was inspired by muzz64's Tidy Tail (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2411911), but was created from scratch for the cable size and wall thickness I needed. (designed for a .4 mm nozzle.)

It is not a remix (his is licensed as "no-derivatives"), but I wanted to give him credit for the inspiration.

I printed in ABS with .2 layer height and support everywhere. There is very little infill, so print with what you like.

It could be rotated and printed without support, but the prongs would be too prone to breaking.

title: QI Under cabinet charger - Ikea Morik QI
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a great hack for anyone that loves the wireless QI charging feature in their Iphone or Android. The ikea MORIK charging assembly is made to be mounted into a table top, which renders it pretty much useless unless you want to drill holes in your furniture. This bracket assembly I designed accepts the MORIK from behind, and nicely holds your phone as an under cabinet mount as it charges.

I designed mine to be used in my workshop and mounted proud, there is no reason that you cannot mount at the back of a cabinet and have it hidden from view.

description.text:
I was not satisfied with the installation of extruder ANETA 8! I had a few issues with the old one and didn't like the following things:

The availability of the extruder motor was poor (to unmount the cooling plate fan)
It was difficult to watch the nozzle while printing because of the clustered design with a large number of components attached to the " printhead»,
High-speed printing was accompanied by a more inaccurate the results due to heavy "print head" with the engine of the extruder

Features of this mount:

Slim, lightweight and modular design
Unobstructed view of the nozzle / as few things as possible in front of the nozzle (cooling fan moved to the left side, leveling sensor rear)
Equipped with multiple zipper slots for proper cable management
Cooling fan at (almost) the same distance to the nozzle as before - > you have a good chance of still using your current cooling channel
Fully compatible with x-axis cable chain

title: iPhone Holder For Car (or anywhere you want!)

description.text:
Self explainatory name! I've seen several holders, but they usually use the vents of the car, and i don't like to block them. This one fits in the gap most cars have for wallet, keys or phones. It uses an M6 screw to adjust the distance of the gap so it can fit different spaces.
Additionally, it could be used in any gap you like, or even be used as a clamp, due to the adjustable holder.
It fits iPhones 4 through 5S (same width), as length is not constrained. I've given it a little space for a case, as most of us use them. I've added the case model i've used, in case someone wants it!
I don't have a 3D printer, so I can't give any printing instructions! The assembly is pretty easy, you can get it from the pictures. Anyway, if help is needed, please let me know.

title: That thing in the Robo3D R2 Ads

description.text:
I bought a Robo3D R2 printer, and in all the pictures, it had this solid on the print bed. I was hoping that it'd be a sample print included with the printer. It wasn't. So, I spent a lot of times squinting at the picture, counting faces and observing the shape of the faces, and eventually determined that it's a Rhobic Enneacontahedron (wire frame) (wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhombic_enneacontahedron), which basically means a 90-faced solid where each face is a rhombus (4 sided equilateral polygon). In this case, two different sizes of Rhombii.

I went on to discover a SCAD generator at http://kitwallace.co.uk/3d/solid-index.xq?id=RhombicEnneacontahedron&mode=solid which is where I got the SCAD file from. Which leaves printing in a way that works.

The item pictured, printed at reduced speed and highest resolution available on the printer took 19 hours, but printing at lower resolution produced something in about 5 (albeit with issues). Still waiting on a weekend to blow off to print a full-sized one (190mm) as we see in the promotional pictures.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

C2 R2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.06mm

Infill:

Whatever

Notes:

Pictured is 100mm in diameter. I initially had stringing issues printing this at .20mm layers, solved by tweaking retraction settings and printing at .06mm layers, which reduced the amount of filament overhang.

This is balanced on a single six-face vertex and will not print upright without support. It's balanced that way to eliminate bridging, but it still requires support to keep it upright. The amount of support depends on layer thickness: at a large thickness (like .20mm), it doesn't need much support, but at finer layer thicknesses, the closer proximity of the extruder can knock the model over, thus the extra support pictured. But, with a properly tweaked printer, it does not need supports for overhangs.

Using default automatically generated supports yielded support containing more filament than the model itself. The model itself really isn't that much filament. I thus had to pare the total support down to something much more manageable.

this is a table top sculptural sign declaring your stance on today's political turmoil.

title: Drone Flight Controller Mount - 20x20 Reducer, Spacers, and RX Deck

description.text:
I designed these components for my Usmile UX2 90MM Drone Frame. Most of the Tiny Whoop Parts wouldn't fit natively. With that, I went ahead and designed a 16MMx16MM Reducer/Stack. This takes 20MMx20MM Flight controllers and reduces the M2/M3 screws and 16MMX16MM layout so you can use Racewhoop or other 16x16's.

The Usmile UX2 frame supports multiple orientations for mounting flight controllers, so I went ahead and adjusted the 16x16 orientation properly as to not need to be done in Betaflight.

My setup:

  • FuriousFPV Racewhoop
  • FuriousFPV Fishpepper 1s-2s 4-in-1 ECU
  • FuriousFPV Mnova 25mW/200mW VTX
  • Frsky XM+ Receiver
  • Runcam Micro Swift 2

Check out my other additions for the Usmile UX2 frame:

Runcam Micro Swift 2 Soft TPU Mount
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2819892

The idea is you thread the M2x5 screws directly from the bottom into the base component. From there, you can use the spacers to add boards. Finally, using the RX PAD at the top to zip tie/hot glue the Receiver.

  • I used four M2x16 screws to tie it all together in a "Hamburger stack" type configuration.
  • The notch on the inside of the circle denotes where the USB of the flight controller should be orientated. The M3 post is 1.5MM smaller to allow for USB cable clearance.

For vibration and dampening I print all these parts in TPU. Worked great! Hopefully someone else can use this design! Good luck!

A compact portable Z-Note (by Post-It) dispenser. Couldn't find one to buy so I quickly designed/made one myself. Easy to throw into your bag.

UPDATE
Added another version of the lid that is more open and reduces the creasing of the post-it note when drawn. Requires less filament and is slightly faster to print. The more open design makes it easy to draw post-its and also makes it easier to remove the lid from the base. The downside is that it provides less protection for the post-its if you intend to keep it knocking around in your bag.

Choose the lid you prefer. You only need to print one of them.

If you want to print both you can press the second lid onto the back of the base and you can carry both of them around (an unintended feature).

description.text:
This is my Action Cam ("Apeman", in my case) mount for my HJC motorcycle helmet. It should also fit for GoPro and other clones. The assembly is easy: Just glue it on your helmet with two double sided sticky foam pads. I recommend 3M VHB pads.

If you're familiar with Blender, you can use the .blend file to adjust the curvature to fit to your helmet. Also, you can adjust the camera mount itself. If you want to change the overall shape, go to the first layer with the modifiers still applied.

Be sure to add support and a raft! Otherwise the print will peel off the bed.

Getting ready

Removing Raft and Support

You might need pliers, a flathead screwdriver and a knive to remove the support. You can break it off easily off the flat parts.

Assembly

You will need the hex nut to screw your camera secure in place in the right angle. For this, use pliers to remove the hex nut that came with the camera from whatever mount it is on.
Now hold it very secure using pliers. Take a lighter or a small gas torch to heat up the hex nut and instantly melt it into your print.

description.text:
Ham-fisted, I recently managed to break the plastic clamp on my trouser hanger (visually identical to this one: http://amzn.to/2oTEAaY). Instead of glueing it together again, I decided to print a replacement piece. It was interesting to learn how slightly different geometries of these clamps actually work (or not).

Since the steel hook in the original product is embedded in the clamp and cannot be removed, I also designed a hook to go with the replacement clamp.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used PETG with 100% infill for maximum structural strength. PLA is not elastic enough and will not work (for the clamp at least), because the clamp needs to tolerate some flex when closed and opened.

Assembly

First, latch the clamp to the metal parts of the trouser hanger like in the original product. Do this before you put together the hook and clamp, because it won't be possible afterwards.

Next, put some glue on the tab of the hook and insert it into the matching slot on the clamp. Wipe off any excess and let the glue harden.

    These connectors will allow the fabrication of almost any shape or enclosure, using the 20x20 mm MakerBean type model from dbozec ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27825 ). Especially desinged to facilitate the construction of experimental laboratory equipment and platforms. The connectors are meant to be glue-"welded" to each other with ABS acetone slurry or cyanomethacrylate (crazy glue).
    With these connectors you can do end-end, corner, rail, groove, flat top or plate, sliding surface, T-pieces end to side and side to side connections, wire guides and mounting or fixation parts. You name it...

Inspired by dbozec's 20x20 mm OpenSCAD MakerBeam design.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27825
Printed on UP!3D on "Fine" for connectors and "Fast" for Z scaled (extruded) beams.
These are some 20mm connectors.
You can Scale (extrude) the rails on the Z axis to make them longer.
The fit is snug so use a bit of rod to move the connectors in the grooves.
Parts (Scale any on Z Axis to make different lengths):
Back row Left to right: Flat top; grooved, MakerBeam
( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27825 ); narrow part for overlying grooved surface; Flat sliding surface; Different flat top.
Middle row: End cap; footer, flat beam; corner with hole; corner.
Front: Wire guide; end joiner, end joiner, side to side joiner; base piece; mounting piece.

This is a small tool we have created for splicing 3D Filament. It is suitable for 1.75 and 3mm filaments. Actually quite a lot of work went into it this 'little thing', we tried to make fully automated splicer first but it failed due several issues such as filament expansion / shrinkage. So manual labor is still the king :) On the filament sample snapshot you can see results, 1 is manual and 2 is done with splicer. Of course you can trim manual joint but it is work and will get annoying soon enough. You can get Splicer copper parts, kit or fully assembled unit via our crowdfunding campaign. We work to bring more color options to OSS 3D Printing and have a few other very interesting ideas. Filament Splicer is first tiny step in this quest.

Bill of materials
  • 6mm plywood frame (see Blueprints)
  • Teflon / PFTE thermal isolation plates, minimum 5mm (see Blueprints)
  • Copper heating and cooling blocks (See Blueprints)
  • 12v thermal controller from Willhi
  • 300c thermal probe with 4mm diameter
  • Cartridge heater
  • 12v 5mm socket, we use high quality metal connector with 10mm neck
  • on/off switch with 12mm neck and M3 terminal screws
  • 12v 6A Power supply
  • 0.5 mm2 wires
  • 4 x 20mm M3 Screws with matching bolts
  • 2 x 7mm M5 Screws with countersunk heads
  • 2 x crimp-on 3mm terminals (Optional for Switch connector)
  • Fast setting wood glue
  • Rubber feet
    • Notes:

  • There is a M3 hole on the top of the heating block, it is for hot knife fixation, there is no blueprint for it, we manufacture it by hand from brass profile, your choice of form. It helps to have a V-Groove in it for easy removal of excess plastic. See pictures of out final product.

    • Thermal isolation plate for heating block should have drilled impression for countersunk screw head to go in. The less hot metal is under the PFTA, the better. Otherwise wood will start charring with time. Box is glued together, it is actually very simple job and our wood glue sets in within 15 minutes. We advise to cover box in protective oil as we do with out kits, otherwise it will get dirty very soon. Do not ever exceed safe operating temperature of PFTA plates (260c in case of our material specs), Teflon emits very nasty fumes when overheated.

description.text:
25 Lotus Flowers is a rotating-piece puzzle I recently invented (at least I'm ignorant of any earlier versions). The object is to turn the 25 lotus Flowers to form a given pattern. The challenge is that each Flower prevents one of its neighbors from turning, so you usually have to turn several Flowers before you can turn the one you want to turn.

I call the puzzle "25 Lotus Flowers" because the 25 puzzle pieces look to me like ancient Egyptian images of lotus flowers, and the addictive nature of the puzzle reminds me of the Lotus Eaters in The Odyssey. By the way, I originally called the puzzle "25 Lotus Leaves" until I found I was thinking of lotus flowers rather than leaves.

I've posted detailed instructions how to play the puzzle, including few challenges for you. Since it's a new puzzle, there are plenty of questions nobody yet knows the answer to - you could be the first to find an answer!

Let me know, in the Comments section here, what you think of the puzzle, and what solutions you've found - let the games begin!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print 25 copies of the Lotus Flower piece, lotusFlower.stl. Print one copy of the board, lotusBoard.stl. The puzzle is prettier if you choose one color for the pieces (such as purple, for lotus leaves) and contrasting color for the board (perhaps sand-color, for the sandstone of Egypt).

This Thing is designed to be printed in PLA, with clearances of 0.5 mm. If you print in ABS, you may have trouble with shrinkage and clearances.

Depending on your printer and filament, you may need to clean the pieces and board edges with a hobby knife before the pieces will rotate well. The print on my Lulzbot Mini with PolyLite PLA only required me to pick off one or two little threads of plastic.

Place the 25 Lotus Flowers (pieces) on the board's pegs in the pattern shown in the first photo or in the FreeCAD file. That is the starting Layout.

I describe several puzzle goals/challenges in the How To page, the object is to turn the pieces, one at a time, to transform the starting Layout a goal Layout. One goal is to create a left-right mirror of the startup Layout. I describe that goal, and harder ones, with illustrations, in the How To page.

I'd been sketching ideas of a turning triangular piece puzzle for (many!) years, without ever constructing the puzzle - it required too much accurate woodworking. Now that I have a 3D printer, I was recently inspired to design the puzzle in FreeCAD and print it. I've made more progress understanding the puzzle in the past week than in the 10 years before, thanks to 3D printing!

As I mentioned above, I designed 0.5 mm clearances throughout: the piece hole radius is 0.5 mm larger than the peg radius; the convex ("outie") curve of the piece has a radius 0.5 mm smaller than the concave ("innie").

I'm interested in making a lid for the puzzle, that keeps all the pieces in place. Right now, it you happen to tip the board over, the pieces all fall out :-(

It doesn't take much to outgrow the stock 775 motor that most 1610 CNC machines come with. Using this adapter you can move past the stock motor's limitations by mounting common 55mm diameter spindles.

This design requires just a few extra parts that are not easily removable from your existing spindle mount:

  • The mounting block your spindle likely came with.
  • M6 screws (and locking bolts for those screws) that are long enough to reach through your mounting block and the printed mount.
  • Four LM8UU bearings.
  • One T8 lead screw nut set having a lead matching the lead screw your Z axis currently uses. My 1610 CNC uses a 4mm lead screw; screws of that lead may be somewhat difficult to find given that 8mm is far more common.
  • Some epoxy for permanently attaching the aforementioned lead screw nut to the printed part. If you look very carefully, you'll notice that there's an inset on the bottom that it will fit snugly within.
  • Ideally a plastic welding chemical that is compatible with the plastic you're printing using for attaching the side supports. The side supports exist as a separate part to make it possible for this to be assembled (while you're attaching this to your CNC, there are screws you will need to reach for the Z-axis's stepper motor that will be extremely difficult to reach once the supports are attached). I printed mine in PETG, and used Weld-on #3. If you print using a different plastic, you may need to find a different plastic welding chemical. Epoxy alone might suffice, but you will have much better Z axis rigidity if you use a welding chemical.

I used this for mounting the spindle from this 400W CNC DC Air Cooled NVBDL+ 12000RPM Brushless Spindle Motor Kit on Amazon (ASIN: B074FVKRZM). If you need to attach a mounting block that uses screws larger than M6 arranged in a 70x20mm square, you may need to alter the design slightly, but the source files are attached. Good luck!

This is not the same exact design as the original Futurecraft 4D. If you guys have better idea how to improve the design let me know.

author: zerosl

description.text:
I almost feel bad for uploading another filament clip :-)

I liked this idea https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:282242 of a clip that clips to another turn of the filament itself to avoid 'spool compatibility' issue altogether, but the one I downloaded didn't hold on very well to the filament when printed with my printer so I decided to design my own. That should not be more than 5 minutes work anyway...

Four prototypes later that were either too tight or too loose I abandoned the design and came up with another one that is not as demanding on precise tolerances to work. It also seemed cumbersome to thread the filament through the hole so I did a symmetric clip that grips both turns of the filament in the same way.

Freecad 0.17 source included in case anyone find it useful and need to adjust it a bit.

My next iteration will include a "key" to fit in a notch cut into the coupler so the switch can stay rotated correctly more easily. Also, the ejection charge hole should be shifted to the side so the charge wire doesn't go so close to the Stratologger programming switch.

This is a model of the gaffi sticks carried by the tusken raiders in various Star Wars films. The dimensions are loosely based on a genuine totokia from Fiji that's part of my collection at home.

It's not a precise replica of any specific gaffi stick, but a general representation of them.

I have not printed it yet, but the notion is that the totokia parts will be wood filament and the mace parts silver.

It's modular, so you can in theory make it break down for transport. The pin is right around 0.5", so a wooden dowel should do the trick for alignment / assembly. I've left some room in the hole for the pins to allow for print layers. I think it should work out, but I'm not 100% sure... Once I print I'll adjust as needed.

If you print one before I do, please let me know how it works out!

EDIT: I just uploaded a version of the totokia bend part that's split down the middle. that might be more easily printable.

EDIT 3/12: Version 2 uploaded! Changes include:

  • round shaft on the totokia with a transition piece to mate it to the oval profile of the bend.
  • center holes 3/4" for the totokia and 1/2" for the mace, so that we can use wood dowels
  • scaled down the mace quite a bit

please note it was kingly brought to my attention some people had issues printing the radio truck's rear section. I have addressed that issue (arose from the cutting I had done to separate the original one piece file). The new file is titled "rear radio cab v. 2.0". I reinforced the piece and smoothed the cab's bottom. thanks to Dominique for bringing this to my attention.

This is a 28mm model of the Maultier half track, a work horse of the Wehrmacht in WW2.

I have taken two much smaller scale one piece models (accredited in this post), up-scaled them to 1/56th (28mm), and broken them into multiple printable parts. One piece prints just do not work in 28mm scale.

For the basic transport Half Track, you will need to print these files :

1) the two front wheels
2) left and right tracks (these are not interchangable; they will tuck ever so slightly into recesses of the chassis
3) the "hull"
4) the cargo cover if you wish a covered bed

The radio truck/Command Post requires you to print these files :

1)1the two front wheels
2) left and right tracks (these are not interchangable; they will tuck ever so slightly into recesses of the chassis
3) the "radio truck chassis
4) the "rear radio cab"
5) the roof mounted "antenna" - print this piece without any brim or support - you will need support for most of the other pieces - it fits into matching recesses in the rear radio cab
6) the "locking nubs" - these fit recesses in the radio truck chassis and the radio cab, to align the parts and ensure they glue up properly
